column94: The genus name Hieracium comes from the Greek word Hierax , which means sparrow hawk, and is based on the belief that hawks improved their vision with the help of the milky juice from the plant. Based on this old notion, herbalists in earlier times used the herb for eye problems, but this use is no longer current.

column94: "blåklokke" is a beautiful plant that everyone, both children and adults, knows. In the past, blåklokke had a special appeal to children, because the flowers could be used for many kinds of toys. All over Norway it was a common game of skill to try to turn the flower without it breaking. On rare occasions it was said that one also had to be able to turn it back. As usual with such games, it was almost always said that if it was successful, one or more wishes would be granted. It was also quite common for children to use the flower to slap. The little girls used the flowers as thimbles, or you could put them in your mouth and blow them out.

Despite its cheerful appearance, the bird’s-foot trefoil symbolizes a warning of revenge in the Victorian language of flowers9.7. The scientific genus name Lotus is an old name for beautiful and useful plants, and is first mentioned by Homer ca. year 800 BC Corniculatus means "with small horns", and comes from the fact that the empty, cracked pods resemble small antelope horns.

It is uncertain how the Norwegian name tiril tongue may have arisen, but it could possibly be a comparison between the inflorescence, or preferably the fruit stand, and a tiril (or turul ), the kernel stick that was formerly used in the upright, cylindrical butter kernels. Tongue refers to the tongue-shaped fan in each individual flower.
column95: In folk medicine in Norway, the plant has been used to a small extent. To the extent that it was used, it was either in the form of a spirit extract of the flowers, or dried leaves and pods were used as tea, which was supposed to be good stomach medicine. The root of tiril tongue has been used as a blood purifier.

column94:
Prikkperikum has a great reputation in folklore and was widely used in magical rituals for protection. One had to pick the plant with the left hand, after asking permission. Wearing Prikkperikum protected against fevers and colds, made soldiers invisible and attracted love. Plants gathered on Midsummer's Eve or on a Friday and worn on the body kept mental illness at bay and cured melancholy. When Prikkperikum was placed in a window, it protected against lightning, fire and evil spirits. Both the flowers and the leaves could be used for this purpose. The herb could also be dried over the midsummer bonfire and hung near a window to keep ghosts, sorcerers and other ill-wishers away from the house, and it could be burned to banish spirits and demons.

If the plant was placed under the pillow of an unmarried woman, she would dream of her future husband. The herb could be used in rituals or carried to detect other magicians, and was once held to the mouths of accused witches in an attempt to force a confession.
column95: It has traditionally been used to treat burns, cuts, bruises and wounds. It is also known for its ability to fight depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), social phobia, and seasonal affective disorder (SAD)8. There was a myth told about this flowering plant5. This plant has marked diversity in strikingly diverse flowers and fruit67. The leaves are either palmately lobed or compound67. The sepals of the flowers are larger than the petals67.

column95: This plant is a loosely tufted herb from short to elongate, extensive rhizomes. Stems are erect, 25-75 cm long[11. Leaves are located on the lower parts of the stem extending at least halfway up, flat, 1.5-3 mm wide[11. Flowers are bright pink and star-shaped with five petals[11.  Cattle may eat saltmarsh rush, but other livestock avoid it. Rabbits sometimes eat its flowers[11.  Saltmarsh rush inhabits salt marshes but has spread away from the coast along salted roadways[12.  It is now found in Vermont where it is introduced[11.  It is mainly a coastal species occurring at the high tide mark on the Mediterranean Atlantic Baltic and Black sea shorelines of Europe and the east coast of North America[12.  It also occurs inland in parts of eastern Europe west and central Asia particularly on saline soils[12.  In North America it occurs along the shorelines of areas once flooded by the sea and as a weed along railway lines for example in Minnesota[12.  In Indiana it is the only Juncus species found in the Tipton Till Plain a Till Plain in the Glacial till plains[12.  It is native to Europe and Western Asia where it grows in moist meadows[8.  Description Hypericum maculatum is a hairless perennial herbaceous plant growing to about 60 cm. The stem is square in cross section but without the wings shown in H. tetrapterum. The leaves are simple entire (undivided) and in opposite pairs without stipules and have few or no translucent glands. There may be black dots on the leaves petals and sepals 1 The flowers are yellow up to about 25mm across. The species hybridises with Hypericum perforatum to produce Des Etang’s St John’s wort Hypericum x desetangsii 1 Uses It is considered to be a medicinal plant 4 Hypericum maculatum herb has been used in the traditional Austrian medicine internally as tea or oil extract and externally as oil extract ointment or cold maceration in ethanol for treatment of disorders of the skin locomotor system nervous system gastrointestinal tract respiratory tract kidneys and urinary tract cardiovascular system infections rheumatism and gout. column94: GRASS. Som beitegras har finnskjegg stort sett vært regnet som dårlig, og direkte farlig for hester: ”Merra hev fått troll når den var blitt syk av finnskjegg” (Ørsta). ”Det har henni at hestan har spist ihjæl seg på setervollan” (Meråker). Til tross for dette ble finnskjegg ofte tatt med i skraphøy fra utslåtter, noe som var mest vanlig i Trøndelag og Nordmøre: ”illt å slå når det e my finn” (Rindal), ”finnskjeggen må en slå tri gang (Glåmos), ”hera ho berre nekke te oss” (Tydal). Ble slått te sauene (Glåmos). ”Hèr er så halbett, vanskelig å få ljåen til å bite på” (Harran).”Bustingen flirer a oss” (Leksvik). ”I fjellet vaks det eit slag gras som dei kalla villgras. Ein måtte akta seg vel so ein ikkje kom ut på det, for så gjekk ein seg vill” (Verdal). ”Når stien vokste igjen av dette graset så den vandrende mistet den, var han kommet på villstrå” (Åsen).

column94:
Yellow ant is not an important medicinal plant these days, but there is a lot of information about its use in earlier times. In the Norse saga era, the yellow ant was consecrated to the fertility goddess Frøya and was therefore called frøyagrass. It was believed that placing a bundle of the herb in the maternity bed alleviated pain during childbirth. Placed in the child's cradle, it was supposed to keep witches and sorcery away. From Christian times, we have the legend that it was the sweet-smelling, soft, yellow-flowering ant that the Virgin Mary used in the manger for the baby Jesus. The old folk name Jomfru Marias sengehalm, which is known from many places in the Nordics, refers precisely to this popular legend. The English name of the plant, Lady's Bedstraw, alludes to the same.

The pleasant, honey-like fragrance of the flowers, and the smell of hay from the dried leaves, made this plant suitable for use as a stuffing in mattresses. It was often mixed with other aromatic herbs and ferns to help keep vermin away from the bed.
column95: Yellow ant has also been used as a beer spice, and has also had some use as a dye plant. The root gives wool a beautiful red colour, while alum-stained wool and silk get a bright yellow color from the above-ground parts. As a source of red color.

column93: The small white flowers grow in a fairly showy panicles from the top of the stem. Each individual flower has 4 pointed segments that fold back from a fused tube enclosing the stamens and pistil.
column94: Galium boreale is known as "bedstraw" because it is used as fragrant stuffing for mattresses.There is also chemical evidence for its roots use in red textile dyes during the "Viking age" (year 800 to 1066). Has been used to dye wool red: "I got a lovely red color from the white ant root, but the root had to be removed before the plant flowered" (Selbu)

column95: The flowers and leaves have long been used in various herbal remedies as poultices, laxatives, and to relieve cough and lung congestion. The Makah women used to eat the violet flowers and leaves during labor. The Klallam mashed the leaves and applied them to the chest or stomach to relieve pain.This is a hairy, compact plant growing from a small rhizome system. The leaves are spade- or heart-shaped, sometimes with broadly wavy margins.
